required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Circle of Life. Improving Capacity of Swampy Cree Community Members to Recognize People at Risk for Suicide
clinical_study.official_title: Circle of Life.Improving Capacity of Swampy Cree Community Members to Recognize People at Risk for Suicide: A Randomized Controlled Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock:
Primary Hypothesis: Participants in the Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) gatekeeper training will be significantly more likely to have increased knowledge and preparedness to help people with suicidal ideation than participants who receive the resilience retreat.
Secondary Hypotheses:
1. Participants in ASIST gatekeeper training will not have higher levels of post-intervention distress or suicidal ideation compared to the resilience retreat.
2. High levels of distress, grief, and alcohol abuse will significantly impact on the learning and retention of suicide intervention skills.

detailed_description.textblock:
Inclusion criterion: All members of the Swampy Cree Tribal communities who are currently residing on the reserves will be eligible to participate in the study.
Exclusion criterion: Exclusion criteria for the study include being less than 16 years of age, prior training in SafeTALK or ASIST, being an elected official in a First Nations community, and inability to read or write.
Primary outcome: Skills in Suicide Intervention: Suicide Intervention Response Inventory.The Suicide Intervention Response Inventory (SIRI) will be used to detect enhancement of intervention skills in participants. The SIRI is a self-administered test that was designed to measure competence in choosing appropriate response to a series of clinical scenarios with suicidal individuals. Research on the SIRI has shown its good psychometric properties, freedom from social desirability effects, and responsiveness to training in suicide prevention. It contains 25 items, each of which consists of a "client" remark and two "helper" responses. Responses are judged based on response options made by highly expert suicidologists. The SIRI has shown good internal consistency with alpha of 0.834, and good test-retest reliability.
Secondary Outcomes:
- Knowledge about suicide, attitudes toward suicide, and self-reported preparedness to intervene with suicidal behavior will be measured by a series of questions that were developed by LivingWorks Inc.
- Gatekeeper behaviors will be measured similar to questions utilized by Wyman in the school-based study that assess how many people had the person asked others about suicide.

primary_outcome.time_frame: pre-training, post-training and 6 mo follow up
primary_outcome.description: The Suicide Intervention Response Inventory (SIRI-2) will be used to detect enhancement of intervention skills in participants. The 25-item SIRI-2 is a self-administered test that was designed to measure competnce in choosing appropriate response to a series of clinical scenarios with suicidal individuals. Research on the SIRI-2 has shown its good psychometric properties, freedom from social desirabiity effects and responsiveness to training in suicide prevention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Self-perceived Confidence in Helping a Suicidal Individual
secondary_outcome.description: Meaures the level of confidence that the individual believes they have in helping a suicidal person based on a 4 point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all confident) to 4 (very confident).

secondary_outcome.measure: Self-perceived Skill in Helping a Suicidal Individual
secondary_outcome.description: Measures the level of ability that the individual believes they have in helping a suicidal person based on a 4 point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all skilled) to 4 (very skilled).
Measures the level of knowledge about suicide that the individual believes they have based on a 4 point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all knowledgeable) to 4 (very knowledgeable).
Measures the level of preparedness of the individual to help someone who is suicidal based on a 4 point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all prepared) to 4 (very prepared).

Measures the level of distress in the participant using the K6 distress scale. The scale is comprised of six questions which are scored from 0 (none of the time) to 4 (all of the time). The sum of the scores from all six questions was used to determine a total scale score which ranges from 0 (not at all distressed) to 24 (very distressed).

Details participants' level of alcohol consumption and if it may be harmful according to the AUDIT. The AUDIT scale is comprised of ten questions with most questions being scored from 0 (never) to 4 (4 or more times per week). The sum of the scores from all ten questions was used to determine a total scale score which ranges from 0 (no risk related to alcohol) to 40 (high risk related to alcohol). Total scores of 8 or more are recommended as indicators of hazardous and harmful alcohol use, as well as possible alcohol dependence.

Assesses resiliency in the participant according to the Connor-Davidson Resilience Scale, 10-item. The CD-RISC 10 is comprised of ten questions scored from 0 (Not at all true) to 4 (True nearly all of the time). The sum of the scores from all ten questions was used to determine a total scale score which ranges from 0 (low resiliency) to 40 (highly resilient).
Number of people who endorsed having thought about suicide in their lifetime as measured at baseline
Number of people who endorsed having made a suicide attempt in their lifetime as measured at baseline

secondary_outcome.measure: Suicidal Ideation in Past 2 Days at Baseline
secondary_outcome.description: Number of people who endorsed having thought about suicide in the past 2 days as measured at baseline (not at all vs a little to a lot)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of People With Suicidal Ideation in Past 2 Days Immediately Post Training
secondary_outcome.description: Number of people who endorsed having thought about suicide in the past 2 days as measured immediately post training (not at all vs a little to a lot)

secondary_outcome.measure: Suicidal Ideation Since Training at 6 mo Follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Number of people who endorsed having thought about suicide since the training as measured at 6 month follow-up (not at all vs a little to a lot)

secondary_outcome.measure: Attempted Suicide Since Training at 6 mo Follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Number of people who endorsed having made a suicide attempt since the training as measured at 6 month follow-up

secondary_outcome.measure: Gatekeeper Behaviors - Asked Person at Risk About Suicidal Thoughts
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants who have asked someone that they thought was at risk about suicidal thoughts since the training, measured at 6 month follow-up assessment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Gatekeeper Behaviours - Did Not Ask Person at Risk
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants who did not ask someone about their suicidal thoughts even though they thought they were at risk, measured at 6 month follow-up assessment based on time since training.

arm_group.description: ASIST is a 2-day intensive, interactive and practice-dominated course aimed at enabling people to recognize risk and learn how to intervene immediately to prevent suicide. The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. Participants range from those in caring roles to people concerned about family members or friends. The theory is that suicide can be pre¬vented with the help of prepared caregivers. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

The two days will be divided into cultural activities, sharing circles, small group discussions, story telling and dance. Two First Nations community leaders will be identified to lead each of the two retreats.

intervention.description: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) is a 2-day, 14 hour suicide intervention skills training workshop.
The Resilience Retreat is a 2-day, 14 hour session

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All members of the Swampy Cree Tribal communities who are currently residing on the reserves will be eligible to participate in the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- being less than 16 years of age
- prior training in SafeTALK or ASIST
- being an elected official in a First Nations community

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Psychiatry, Faculty of Medicine, University of Manitoba

facility.name: University of Manitoba Department of Psychiatry

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Various methods of advertising for volunteers was used (i.e., radio advertisements, newsletters, posters). Community activities were organized by community representatives in an effort to recruit individuals to participate in the study (i.e., through a bingo night, barbecue, etc.) between May 2010 and May 2011.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: From all eligible applications, we selected participants using a random number generator based on receipt of application until we had six adolescents, four adults, and two elders in each community who met criteria for participation in the study.

group.title: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST)
group.description: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) is a 2-day, 14 hour suicide intervention skills training workshop. ASIST is an intensive, interactive and practice-dominated course aimed at enabling people to recognize risk and learn how to intervene immediately to prevent suicide. The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. Participants range from those in caring roles to people concerned about family members or friends. The theory is that suicide can be pre¬vented with the help of prepared caregivers. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

group.title: Resilience Retreat
group.description: The 2-day 14-hour resilience retreat (RR) was divided into cultural teachings and activities, sharing circles, small group discussions, and story telling. The RR included four main components: (1) Seven Sacred Teachings; (2) Self-identity—focused on knowing your identity, the past, and celebrating your history. Following the presentation, participants divided into community groups for discussion and then reconvened with all attendees to share discussion points; (3) Healthy communities—explored and discussed questions regarding healthy communities using both verbal and pictorial explanations; (4) Bracelet-making activity. The RR ended with a sharing circle attended by all participants.

participants_list.participants: number of people that were invited to participate based on eligibility and consent received
number of people that were invited to participate based on eligibility and consent received
number of people that showed up for the training session
number of people that showed up for the training session
all participants that had completed the baseline measure were invited to do the follow-up
all participants that had completed the baseline measure were invited to do the follow-up

baseline.population: The number of baseline participants reflects the number of participants that showed up on the day of training, as that was our first point of contact and the time point at which the baseline questionnaire was given. This is different than the number of people that we invited to participate in the study.

Participants range from those in caring roles to people concerned about family members or friends. The theory is that suicide can be pre¬vented with the help of prepared caregivers. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: SIRI Questionnaire Score
measure.description: The Suicide Intervention Response Inventory (SIRI-2) will be used to detect enhancement of intervention skills in participants. The 25-item SIRI-2 is a self-administered test that was designed to measure competnce in choosing appropriate response to a series of clinical scenarios with suicidal individuals. Research on the SIRI-2 has shown its good psychometric properties, freedom from social desirabiity effects and responsiveness to training in suicide prevention.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that the groups would not differ in terms of SIRI scores across the three time points. We used linear mixed models to determine whether scores were different between the two groups over time.
analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for statistical significance was set at p<.05. Effect size determined by partial eta-squared to be 0.01.
analysis.method_desc: Model was adjusted for differences in educational attainment at baseline.

outcome.description: Meaures the level of confidence that the individual believes they have in helping a suicidal person based on a 4 point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all confident) to 4 (very confident).

The sum of the scores from all six questions was used to determine a total scale score which ranges from 0 (not at all distressed) to 24 (very distressed).
outcome.population: The smaller number of participants per group reflects the number of individuals who responded to the baseline and 6 month follow up time point questionnaires.

Total scores of 8 or more are recommended as indicators of hazardous and harmful alcohol use, as well as possible alcohol dependence.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis was that the groups would not differ in terms of alcohol use across the two time points.
analysis.p_value_desc: A priori threshold for significance set at p<.05.
analysis.method_desc: Model was adjusted for differences in educational attainment at baseline.

The CD-RISC 10 is comprised of ten questions scored from 0 (Not at all true) to 4 (True nearly all of the time). The sum of the scores from all ten questions was used to determine a total scale score which ranges from 0 (low resiliency) to 40 (highly resilient).

group.title: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST)
group.description: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) is a 2-day, 14 hour suicide intervention skills training workshop. ASIST is an intensive, interactive and practice-dominated course aimed at enabling people to recognize risk and learn how to intervene immediately to prevent suicide. The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. Participants range from those in caring roles to people concerned about family members or friends. The theory is that suicide can be pre¬vented with the help of prepared caregivers. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

group.title: Resilience Retreat
group.description: The 2-day 14-hour resilience retreat (RR) was divided into cultural teachings and activities, sharing circles, small group discussions, and story telling. The RR included four main components: (1) Seven Sacred Teachings; (2) Self-identity—focused on knowing your identity, the past, and celebrating your history. Following the presentation, participants divided into community groups for discussion and then reconvened with all attendees to share discussion points; (3) Healthy communities—explored and discussed questions regarding healthy communities using both verbal and pictorial explanations; (4) Bracelet-making activity. The RR ended with a sharing circle attended by all participants.

measure.title: Self-reported Resiliency Score
measure.description: Assesses resiliency in the participant according to the Connor-Davidson Resilience Scale, 10-item. The CD-RISC 10 is comprised of ten questions scored from 0 (Not at all true) to 4 (True nearly all of the time). The sum of the scores from all ten questions was used to determine a total scale score which ranges from 0 (low resiliency) to 40 (highly resilient).
measure.population: The smaller number of participants per group reflects the number of individuals who responded to the baseline and 6 month follow up time point questionnaires.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that the two groups would not differ in resiliency scores across the follow-up period.
analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for statistical significance was set at p<.05.
analysis.method_desc: Model is adjusted for differences in educational attainment at baseline.

outcome.title: Lifetime Suicidal Ideation at Baseline
outcome.description: Number of people who endorsed having thought about suicide in their lifetime as measured at baseline

group.title: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST)
group.description: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) is a 2-day, 14 hour suicide intervention skills training workshop. ASIST is an intensive, interactive and practice-dominated course aimed at enabling people to recognize risk and learn how to intervene immediately to prevent suicide. The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. Participants range from those in caring roles to people concerned about family members or friends. The theory is that suicide can be pre¬vented with the help of prepared caregivers. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

group.title: Resilience Retreat
group.description: The 2-day 14-hour resilience retreat (RR) was divided into cultural teachings and activities, sharing circles, small group discussions, and story telling. The RR included four main components: (1) Seven Sacred Teachings; (2) Self-identity—focused on knowing your identity, the past, and celebrating your history. Following the presentation, participants divided into community groups for discussion and then reconvened with all attendees to share discussion points; (3) Healthy communities—explored and discussed questions regarding healthy communities using both verbal and pictorial explanations; (4) Bracelet-making activity. The RR ended with a sharing circle attended by all participants.

measure.title: Lifetime Suicidal Ideation at Baseline
measure.description: Number of people who endorsed having thought about suicide in their lifetime as measured at baseline

analysis.p_value_desc: A priori threshold for significance set at p<.05.

outcome.title: Lifetime Suicide Attempt at Baseline
outcome.description: Number of people who endorsed having made a suicide attempt in their lifetime as measured at baseline

group.title: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST)
group.description: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) is a 2-day, 14 hour suicide intervention skills training workshop. ASIST is an intensive, interactive and practice-dominated course aimed at enabling people to recognize risk and learn how to intervene immediately to prevent suicide. The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. Participants range from those in caring roles to people concerned about family members or friends. The theory is that suicide can be pre¬vented with the help of prepared caregivers. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

Following the presentation, participants divided into community groups for discussion and then reconvened with all attendees to share discussion points; (3) Healthy communities—explored and discussed questions regarding healthy communities using both verbal and pictorial explanations; (4) Bracelet-making activity. The RR ended with a sharing circle attended by all participants.

measure.description: Number of people who endorsed having made a suicide attempt in their lifetime as measured at baseline

Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

outcome.title: Number of People With Suicidal Ideation in Past 2 Days Immediately Post Training
outcome.description: Number of people who endorsed having thought about suicide in the past 2 days as measured immediately post training (not at all vs a little to a lot)
outcome.population: The smaller number of participants per group reflects the number of individuals who responded to the post-training questionnaire.

The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. Participants range from those in caring roles to people concerned about family members or friends. The theory is that suicide can be pre¬vented with the help of prepared caregivers. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

outcome.description: Number of people who endorsed having made a suicide attempt since the training as measured at 6 month follow-up

ASIST is an intensive, interactive and practice-dominated course aimed at enabling people to recognize risk and learn how to intervene immediately to prevent suicide. The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. The RR included four main components: (1) Seven Sacred Teachings; (2) Self-identity—focused on knowing your identity, the past, and celebrating your history. measure.title: Attempted Suicide Since Training at 6 mo Follow-up
measure.description: Number of people who endorsed having made a suicide attempt since the training as measured at 6 month follow-up
measure.population: The smaller number of participants per group reflects the number of individuals who responded to the 6 month follow up time point questionnaire.

outcome.title: Gatekeeper Behaviors - Asked Person at Risk About Suicidal Thoughts
outcome.description: Number of participants who have asked someone that they thought was at risk about suicidal thoughts since the training, measured at 6 month follow-up assessment.
outcome.population: The smaller number of participants per group reflects the number of individuals who responded to the baseline and 6 month follow up time point questionnaires.

group.title: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST)
group.description: Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) is a 2-day, 14 hour suicide intervention skills training workshop. ASIST is an intensive, interactive and practice-dominated course aimed at enabling people to recognize risk and learn how to intervene immediately to prevent suicide. The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. Participants range from those in caring roles to people concerned about family members or friends. The theory is that suicide can be pre¬vented with the help of prepared caregivers. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

group.title: Resilience Retreat
group.description: The 2-day 14-hour resilience retreat (RR) was divided into cultural teachings and activities, sharing circles, small group discussions, and story telling. The RR included four main components: (1) Seven Sacred Teachings; (2) Self-identity—focused on knowing your identity, the past, and celebrating your history. Following the presentation, participants divided into community groups for discussion and then reconvened with all attendees to share discussion points; (3) Healthy communities—explored and discussed questions regarding healthy communities using both verbal and pictorial explanations; (4) Bracelet-making activity. The RR ended with a sharing circle attended by all participants.

measure.title: Gatekeeper Behaviors - Asked Person at Risk About Suicidal Thoughts
measure.description: Number of participants who have asked someone that they thought was at risk about suicidal thoughts since the training, measured at 6 month follow-up assessment.
measure.population: The smaller number of participants per group reflects the number of individuals who responded to the baseline and 6 month follow up time point questionnaires.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis was that the groups would not differ in terms of their gatekeeper behaviours
analysis.p_value_desc: a priori threshold for significance set a p<.05.

outcome.title: Gatekeeper Behaviours - Did Not Ask Person at Risk
outcome.description: Number of participants who did not ask someone about their suicidal thoughts even though they thought they were at risk, measured at 6 month follow-up assessment based on time since training.
outcome.population: The smaller number of participants per group reflects the number of individuals who responded to the baseline and 6 month follow up time point questionnaires.

ASIST is an intensive, interactive and practice-dominated course aimed at enabling people to recognize risk and learn how to intervene immediately to prevent suicide. The training is designed for anyone (especially those in a position of trust), from professionals and volunteers to members of the community. ASIST is designed to help all caregivers become more willing, ready and able to help persons at risk. Just as "CPR" skills make physical first aid possible, training in suicide intervention develops the skills used in suicide first aid.

measure.description: Number of participants who did not ask someone about their suicidal thoughts even though they thought they were at risk, measured at 6 month follow-up assessment based on time since training.
measure.population: The smaller number of participants per group reflects the number of individuals who responded to the baseline and 6 month follow up time point questionnaires.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis was that the groups would not differ on gatekeeper behaviours.
analysis.p_value_desc: A priori threshold for significance set at p<.05.

reported_events.time_frame: From baseline time point to 6 months.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
